main event: A white object, as bright as a first magnitude star, was sighted at 34-47N, 166-19W, and observed for 4 minutes before disappearing over the horizon.
interesting points: The object was observed visually with binoculars by the lookout, the Officer of the Deck, and five watch standers, who were considered reliable witnesses.
The object was first observed at an elevation of 10 degrees, bearing 195 degrees true, heading northeast, and then disappeared over the horizon on a bearing of 175 degrees true.
The sighting occurred at 0407Z on September 8, 1961, with clear atmospheric conditions (CAVU).
The object was described as a white, bright object, as bright as a first magnitude star.
The object's behavior included flying erratically at an altitude of approximately 25,000 feet before disappearing over the horizon.
sighted object: a white, bright object, as bright as a first magnitude star
witnesses: the lookout, the Officer of the Deck, and five watch standers
